MALONE IS SUDDENLY YANKED HEAD-FIRST INTO THE BELLY OF TH

PAST HER, MISSING THE LEDGE BY INCHES, DISAPPEARING INTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the small, glass-enclosed room, the MAN sets a pen ink on a writing table. He opens a leather-bound book, th cover of which reads:

dialogues.speaker: JOURNAL OF PATRICK MALONE
dialogues.text: He inks the pen and begins to write.

dialogues.speaker: MALONE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: April 21st, 1905. The die is cast...

dialogues.speaker: ON A STRETCH OF WHITE SAND BEACH
dialogues.text: TWELVE MEN stand in a line. Some hold kerosene lamps. All are dressed in black, like their mood.

dialogues.speaker: MALONE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A vote has been taken and our decision made. I have volunteered to carry-out the deed, much to the dismay of my Erica and the children... MALONE moves down the line of men. The last of them hands him an official-looking PARCHMENT, rolled and tied with a ribbon. Without ceremony, MALONE turns and walks towards

dialogues.speaker: THE OCEAN
dialogues.text: Where two OARSMEN shove a longboat into the surf. MALONE gets in, and we’1l notice some cargo, lashed-down under a tarp.

dialogues.speaker: MALONE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My mind races with the thought of what I must now do. Of what must be done. And as they put out to sea, MALONE looks back to find... ELEVEN MEN standing on the beach. Silent. Watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEADY ROWING is the only SOUND we hear. MALONE sits rapt thought, when something up ahead catches his eye. The OARSMEN stop rowing and we REVERSE ANGLE to reveal an advancing FOG BANK, not 50 fee ahead. The OARSMEN look to MALONE.

dialogues.speaker: MALONE
dialogues.text: Afraid of a little fog, are we? He nods at them to press on. They pick up the rhythm agai disappearing into the swirling mist... INT. A SHIP’S HOLD ~- NIGHT MOVING through the belly of a clipper ship, a labyrinth o light and shadow, lit by hanging lanterns swaying from th rafters. There are PEOPLE in here, scurrying about, performing wha we'd guess are their assigned duties. They are oddly dres in cloak and shroud, and we cannot see their faces. A MAN, dressed like the others, descends the creaky stair into the hold. His name is BLAKE, and we can tell by the deference paid him, he is their leader. He walks amongst them with his lantern, offering a gentle on the back or a quiet nod...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLAKE enters the room. A WOMAN sits at a dressing table, facing away from us, brushing her long, dark hair. We not her HAIRBRUSH -- made of pure gold, engraved with INTRICA PATTERNS... On hearing BLAKE enter, she pulls her shroud up over her and turns. We see her only in profile, and from this angl she is unmistakably beautiful. BLAKE walks over to her. She looks up at him, uneasy. Reassuringly, he reaches out to touch her face.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Don't worry. This is a new beginning. For all of us. When he pulls his hand away, there is milky-white MAGGOT wriggling on his fingertip. This doesn’t seem to bother h in the least, as he flicks the thing away. Then he leans in to kiss her and his lantern lights the of her face we couldn’t quite see... ...covered in pus-filled boils and sagging, gangrenous tissue. But her eyes are alive and filled with love for t man. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's as if we’ve been swallowed whole by a thick and undulating fog, creeping in on us from every side. Again, PICK UP the ROWING SOUND... ...which seems to be coming at us, then we could swear it moving away. We’re becoming more and more disoriented now Up is down and down is up and soon the SOUND seems to wra around us like the fog itself, when...

dialogues.speaker: THE BOW OF THE LONGBOAT
dialogues.text: PIERCES the mist. There’s a DULL THUD as the LONGBOAT ban into something not yet seen. The OARSMEN stow their oars MALONE raises his lantern and WE SEE WHAT THEY'VE HIT... THE BATTERED HULL OF THE CLIPPER SHIP. Light spills from tiny portholes belowdecks, illuminating name painted on her bow:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH DANE
dialogues.text: MALONE draws a pistol. The OARSMEN look surprised. MALONE reaches out, RAPPING on the Dane’s hull with the butt:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a pair of embracing hands. WIDEN to reveal they belong to BLAKE and the WOMAN. He gets up to leave, but s doesn’t want to let go.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: It’s going to be fine. I promise you with all my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MALONE sits in the LONGBOAT, pistol stowed, bobbing along the DANE, when A CLOAKED SHAPE leans out over the gunwale BLAKE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Williams?

dialogues.speaker: MALONE
dialogues.text: (looking away) Yes. BLAKE disappears momentarily. A leather SATCHEL comes fly over the rail, practically hits MALONE in the head. MALONE takes out the PARCHMENT we saw earlier, places it the satchel, flings it back up on deck.

dialogues.speaker: MALONE
dialogues.text: Leave the gold on deck and get your people down below. I/’11 not ~ subject myself to your wretched... A rope-ladder is dropped over the side. The OARSMEN rise.

dialogues.speaker: MALONE
dialogues.text: Wait. MALONE takes out a knife, slashes open the tarp, revealin the cargo: three large cans marked KEROSENE. The shocked OARSMEN look to MALONE -- nobody said anything about this EXT. ELIZABETH DANE’S DECK ~- NIGHT First one up, MALONE lifts his lantern. The deck appears empty, save for a rusted metal CHEST. MALONE goes over an flips open the lid to find it brimming with GOLD COINS. He dips into it, letting the cold wealth run through his fingers, startled when HE HEARS SOMETHING... MALONE holds up his lantern, sees BLAKE’s cloaked shape standing at the bow.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: You’re not Williams.

dialogues.speaker: MALONE
dialogues.text: No. But I represent his interests. His, and the rest of the town fathers. MALONE'S hand slips behind his back, producing the PISTOL

dialogues.speaker: MALONE
dialogues.text: We want the rest of your gold, Blake. All of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ’ The deal we made was more than fair. Take what's there, and go. MALONE nods to the OARSMEN who crack open the KEROSENE, b dousing the Dane’s wooden deck.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: In God's name, what kind of people are you? MALONE lights a wooden match with his thumbnail, holds it over the deck -- something for BLAKE to think about.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Alright! I’11 need to go below.

dialogues.speaker: MALONE
dialogues.text: (blows out the match) Go on. But if you try anything, the ship burns. MALONE turns the pistol on his own men.

dialogues.speaker: MALONE
dialogues.text: Go with him. ~

dialogues.speaker: OARSMAN
dialogues.text: Please... Don’t make us go down there... With them.

dialogues.speaker: MALONE
dialogues.text: Down there... {cocks the pistol) Or up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We descend into the ship's hold, crowded with BLAKE'S peo The OARSMEN follow BLAKE, covering their noses at the unbearable stench. EXT. ELIZABETH DANE’S DECK - LATER ~- NIGHT MALONE stands waiting impatiently at the hatchway. One of the OARSMEN starts to come up the ladder. MALONE puts his boot on the man’s shoulder. .

dialogues.speaker: MALONE
dialogues.text: Gold first. Then you. A heavy CHEST is thrust upwards. MALONE grabs it by the handle... The OARSMAN starts back up the ladder, when MALONE kicks in the teeth, sending him tumbling back down. MALONE kicks over a full can of KEROSENE, which goes spil into the hold. BLAKE looks out from the shadow of his clo EYES dark and malevolent, fixing MALONE with a cursed sta MALONE recoils at this, dropping his lantern into the hol We hear a WHUMPH as the kerosene ignites. And then we hea the SCREAMS as MALONE slams the hatch shut. He shoots the bolt across and BASHES THE HASP, rendering it useless, sealing them in. Forever. In a hurry now, MALONE slides the first chest to the edge the deck, but it’s heavy and he’1]l never get it down the ladder by himself. In a greedy panic, he spots the Dane’s lifeboat, suspended by ropes at deck level.

dialogues.speaker: THE LIFEBOAT
dialogues.text: MALONE has loaded both chests into the lifeboat. SMOKE billows up through the planks of the Dane’s deck. People SCREAMING down below, POUNDING for a way out. MALONE gets into the lifeboat, takes his knife and SLASHE the ropes holding him aloft... But one of the ropes SNAGS in a pulley, dropping the bow sharply. The weight of the chests sends them SMASHING through the first two bench seats, threatening to crash r through the bow and into the water. MALONE LUNGES FOR THEM as the lids POP OPEN, sending hund of gold coins to the bottom of the sea, when The hung rope FREES ITSELF. The life boat falls, smacking down into the water. Relieved, MALONE turns his back on t smoldering ship, picking gold coins off the floor of the lifeboat, when A HAND SMASHES THROUGH ONE OF THE PORTHOLES, burnt flesh dripping from the bone, locking MALONE in a death grip! Out of his wits, MALONE struggles to break free, HACKING the hideous hand, bashing at it with an oar as the SCREAM from inside the DANE build into an unholy frenzy. With a last, bone-crunching WHACK, the hand withers and MALONE is free. He rows away from the doomed ship using a his strength, gliding past. a barnacle-encrusted BUOY... And WE HOLD ON THE BUOY, bobbing in the ocean, as a hund years of time and tide pass before our eyes... A SLEEK WHITE CHARTER BOAT powers past the BUOY, splashin with a glassy sheet of water. NICK CASTLE, 20, is on the FLYBRIDGE, at the helm of this foot luxo SPORT-FISHING BOAT. His hair is blown back by t wind, emphasizing his raw good looks. His SWEATSHIRT tell us who he’s working for: ANTONIO BAY SPORT-FISHING CHARTE WORKING THE REAR OF THE BOAT is BRETT SPOONER, 20, Nick's best friend and fellow employee. Simple, honest, made of good stuff, SPOONER’S got a mop of surfer’s hair, and has yet lost all his baby fat... SPOONER uses a mean-looking BONING KNIFE to splay open a yellowfin, while TWO SUNBURNED FISHERMEN drink beer after day on the water. SPOONER offers up a slice of raw tuna.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: Sushi? The FISHERMEN decline, so SPOONER happily sucks it down, as the boat breezes by us, we'll notice the name painted stern: SEAGRASS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the SEAGRASS glides-in under the harbor lights, NICK begins STRIPPING down to his boxers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK expertly parks the boat in its slip. He shuts down t engines, grabs his clothes and slides down the ladder ont the deck, where the FISHERMEN are gathering their gear.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (in a hurry) Thanks for your business, guys. See you next year. Hustle it up, would you, Spooner? SPOONER pulls two big fish from the FREEZER in the hold.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: Dude. Nice underpants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPOONER enters the cabin, looking for NICK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, Nick!

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: In here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK stands shirtless, lean and muscled, hair wet from a shower. He buttons his jeans, straps on his watch, checks the time -- he’s way late. SPOONER dances into the doorway, stands beside NICK in th mirror. He pulls his shirt up over his considerable belly

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: Look -- twins.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Dream on.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: Not you an’ me. These. SPOONER starts tracing little circles around his nipples.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Don’t bug me, Spooner. I’m late.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: For what? We still got decks to swab.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Elizabeth's coming home tonight. I’m picking her up at the train.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, wait. I remember you telling me this...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: So you do have one brain cell left...

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: ...to which I think’I responded, her mom will slice off your teeny weeny little balls, and have herself a Nick's special. (of£ NICK’S look) Testicle on rye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw her mom.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: I tried. I think my Soloflex abs were too much for her. SPOONER picks up NICK’S brush, starts brushing his own mo It’s hopeless.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: I thought Elizabeth and her mom ~ were in some big hatefest.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I don't know. Just back me up on this, alright? Hose down the boat and gas it up for tomorrow. That way, we won't get fired.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: We?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah, we. Like, we need to keep our jobs so we can buy our own boat some day...

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: Oh, that we.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (out the door) See you at the beach party.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: By the way, how do you plan to handle the thing between you and Stevie? NICK stops, turns, puts his hands on SPOONER’S shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Spooner. That was a one-time thing. And I regret it. (checks his watch again) I am so late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK drives down MAIN STREET of the quaint little coastal town, past Jimmy's Chowder Shack and the Rainy Ale Tavern  10. He passes the Tasty-Freeze and Tisdale's Hardware, and th we notice the BLEACHERS erected on either side of the str and the BANNERS proclaiming Antonio Bay’s 100th birthday celebration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a low-hanging ground fog rounds a corner and begins spreading towards us. It flows over sidewalks and into th streets...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK drives the road out of town, a can of Bud between hi legs, about to take a swig, when he notices A SHERIFF’S PICKUP TRUCK parked on a berm beside the road The door is open and we can see the SHERIFF walking up to A BIG FOR SALE sign, planted in the ground. WORDING on th sign: 50 acres, prime development site, artist's renderin of some cookie-cutter condos, phone number, etc. NICK slows, watching as the SHERIFF hammers something ont the sign. He yells out the window.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What‘re you doin to that sign?

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SHERIFF
dialogues.text: He looks over and smirks. The brass bar opposite his badg reads MALONE. In his 40’s, he was handsome once, but TOM MALONE now has the look of a man who has lost his edge... He takes a step towards NICK’S truck, and we can see the plaque he just nailedon: SOLD

dialogues.speaker: . SHERIFF
dialogues.text: What’re you doin way out here, Hotrod?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Just goin for a ride. Somebody finally buy that land, or what?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Don’t you worry about it. Let’s just say I won't be Sheriff of this dump much longer... NICK eyes him, trying to put it together...  11.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: ‘What the hell’re you lookin at? (then) I don’t smell beer in that truck, do I?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No sir. Not unless it’s Root Beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That‘s good. Now you go on and enjoy your ride. And be sure and obey those little white signs with the numbers in ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yes sir. (under his breath) Prick. NICK smiles and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK swigs his beer now, scenery whipping by outside the window. He shifts the truck into high gear.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The headlights illuminate the winding road, cutting throu dense green forest. Pockets of MIST swirl and drift acros the road... From the RADIO in the dash, we HEAR a sensual female voic

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It’s nine-thirty on a beautiful Friday night in Antonio Bay. I’m Stevie Wayne, and I’m gonna go a little ‘old school’ on you tonight. Here's a track from [Ramones, etc.] on KAB, 94.5, and streaming over the web at kabtunes.com. KAB -- your alternative to the modern music establishment.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (smiling) ...the voice that launched a thousand ships.  12. MUSIC comes over the radio. NICK reaches down to turn up volume, and when he glances up:

dialogues.speaker: ENTERING A POCKET OF MIST
dialogues.text: It's a white-out. WHEN SUDDENLY,

dialogues.speaker: A GIRL APPEARS IN THE MIST
dialogues.text: NICK SWERVES and hits the brakes, watching her in the headlights as he passes by. She’s hitch-hiking, a suitcas at her feet. And she’s hot. He checks his watch again, looks back at the GIRL as if t And now she’s eyeing him, too...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Shit. He puts on the brakes, makes a’u-turn and goes back for h He pulls over, rolls down his window.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: "Hi.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Hi, yourself.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Don’t you know hitch-hiking is dangerous? The GIRL just shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You want a ride?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: But you’re headed in the wrong direction.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (with a big smile) Not anymore. . The GIRL picks up her suitcase, sashays around the front the truck and opens the door. She is barely 20, beautiful and strong -- a dream of a girl-next-door.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You're not a freak or anything. Are you?  13.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah. Actually I am.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (smiling) She gets in and closes the door. She looks straight ahead but they aren’t going anywhere. She finally turns to NICK, who looks at her with gleaming almost mesmeric eyes. She starts to say something, when h reaches out, tracing the line of her jaw, her lips. Suddenly she’s all over him and he just rolls with it. So they are reaching inside each other’s clothes, popping buttons, sliding down in the seat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I missed you... (stops kissing him) And Nick?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yes, Elizabeth...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Next time, don’t be late. They go at it again, quickly disappearing from view. CAMERA SLOWLY BOOMS UP from the truck, RISING through the trees, to reveal the STARS, the craggy COASTLINE, and a familiar-looking LIGHTHOUSE out on the point. Its BEACON strakes the horizon, fingering the darkness, ~ moving on, as we HEAR...

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It's a little after 10 o’clock and I'm Stevie Wayne, your very own beacon in-the-night... CAMERA races at the LIGHTHOUSE with lightning speed, BLIN for an instant by the LIGHT on top as it whooshes by agai and now we're INSIDE that same small, glass-enclosed room at the top of eld stone lighthouse -- now the broadcast booth of KAB. CLOSE ON STEVIE WAYNE -- 20’s, funkily sensual, a young J Jett type. Her hair is. up and she wears a cut-up Ramones shirt. She uses her bare foot to adjust the mike.  14.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: I'm high tonight in the KAB lighthouse on Spivey Point... and I’m being paid the big bucks to remind everybody this Sunday marks Antonio Bay’s 100th anniversary... Dammit ! PULL BACK to find STEVIE sitting at her console, one foot the board, painting her toe nails with deep purple polish She grabs a kleenex to dab a smudge...

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: .-you can say that on the radio nowadays. Anyway, by now you know the drill. The big shin-dig is planned for Sunday, with a surprise performance by a local band you won’t wanna miss. So go, she said, and if you don’t have a date, you can always take me along to keep you company. She flips a switch and another SONG begins to play. Instantly, the phones LIGHT UP. STEVIE looks flatly at th flashing lights.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: I don’t mean literally, you morons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights on the MERRY-MARKET SIGN go out. A HAND turns CLOSED SIGN in the window. The GROUND FOG hovers outside door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BAG BOY picks up his broom, cranks the volume on his ra as the song Stevie just cued plays in the b.g. He goes to straighten a display of canned goods, when something make » him stop... He looks around the store, eying the creepy old curios dangling from the ceiling, hanging on walls, etc. -- Shaking it off, he starts to sweep, when the lights insid the soda cases begin to flicker and buzz. BOTTLES start CLINKING together on the shelves. The whole place starts to. RATTLE AND HUM now, as stuff falls and b in the aisles.  15.

dialogues.speaker: BAG BOY
dialogues.text: Shit! It’s the big one! He drops his broom and races for the exit, when he sees: THE AUTOMATIC DOORS slamming open and shut all on their o fast, and erratic -- lethal even -- and when he turns, he sees something that freezes him in his tracks: MICROWAVE POPCORN starts to POP. Still in the packages. Right on the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen on the ATM begins BUZZING with a weird, sepia- FLUX. It looks like there’s an IMAGE trying to form somewhere in there, but then we hear the KA-CHUNK of the dispenser, as TWENTIES begin spitting from the machine. An OLD LADY passes by, her eyeglasses on a decorative cha around her neck. At first she just keeps walking, but whe she realizes no one is watching, she goes back, scooping bills into her purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closed. Dark. The AIR HOSE DING-DING’s. But there’s nobod there. One of the gas NOZZLES falls off the pump, begins dischar GASOLINE, which slowly spreads across the parking lot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window, we see DOGS GOING NUTS in their cages barking at the moon, spinning, chasing their tails...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There’s a cheery SIGN out front, with a digital TIME/TEMP display. The thing is going haywire -- 34 o’clock, 299 degrees, etc. And for the briefest moment, we could swear spells out a word: DANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A burned-out BEACHCOMBER in a tattered navy pea coat shuf up the beach. In one hand is a METAL DETECTOR, which he waves over the sand. In the other is a FLASK. He takes a drink and we notice his thrashed sea captain's and a headset that attaches to the metal detector. He gru as the booze goes down, looks up with bloodshot eyes.  16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC PLAYS OVER a dozen young PARTIERS, hanging out arou blazing BONFIRE, guzzling beer, making out, passing a doo etc. NICK and ELIZABETH are here, along with their friends SEA REED and EMILY MOSS. NICK puts his arm around ELIZABETH, pulls her close.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hey. You happy?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Mmmm-hmmm .

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You look good enough to eat, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Bon a petit... NICK gets an evil smile. She kisses him deeply. Young lov The SONG we’ve been listening to ENDS, and we hear STEVIE VOICE over the airwaves:

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s almost midnight on KAB, I'm still Stevie Wayne, and I'd like to send a shout out to my good friend, Elizabeth Williams, Antonio Bay’s favorite college girl. Welcome home, Lizzy. This one’s for you. A new song PLAYS. The friends raise their beers, ad libbi toasts, which ELIZABETH shyly accepts.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Stevie’s extremely cool. SEAN saunters up with fresh beers, shoots NICK a look he pretends not to see. He hands ELIZABETH a beer.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, Elizabeth. Welcome back to dullsville. Hey Nickster. Let's go water the sand... NICK and SEAN get up, move off into the darkness. EMILY scoots closer to ELIZABETH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something nor EMILY

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: So. What’s it like?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: College guys. The parties. The dorms. You know...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It’s fine, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: . EMILY
dialogues.text: Fine? I thought it'd be like, exotic. And glamorous.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Well, let’s see. I’ve gained five pounds from the dorm food. There’s a big, hairy Russian chick on my floor that stares at me in the showers, and two of my professors have hit on me, only one of whom is male.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (dreamy) That's awesome. Sure beats Antonio Bay... smiles a sad little smile, suddenly looks away...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Did you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I dunno, I thought I... Nevermind. sweeps behind ELIZABETH in a blur, but neither she sees it. shrugs if off, POPS open her beer, when COMES HURTLING out of the darkness landing SMACK IN EMILY’S LAP -- viscera and mandibles and shell -- like th skittering ALIEN on the guy’s face in the movie... EMILY and it’s just ELIZABETH JUMP UP SCREAMING, until they realize a DEAD SPINY LOBSTER upside-down in the sand.  18. NICK and SEAN run up laughing, high-fiving each other.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Hardy-har, children.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: That's so not cool!

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You shoulda seen your faces. Suddenly, A PALE WHITE FACE appears in the darkness behin them, seems to hover there.

dialogues.speaker: FACE
dialogues.text: Boo! The whole group JUMPS! It’s the BEACHCOMBER. NICK © Jesus, Machen! What the hell do you want? MACHEN looks around, sizing up the partiers with lusty ey

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: I'll take a Bud if you got it.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Machen. I got yer beer. Go fetch. SEAN fakes like he’s gonna throw the can, when ELIZABETH takes it, hands it politely to MACHEN.

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: Thank you..

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You're welcome. MACHEN guzzles some beer which runs down his chin, while eyeballs the taped-together metal detector.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You been up and down the beach with that thing every day since I can remember. What the hell’re you looking for? MACHEN reaches into his pocket, pulls out a gleaming GOLD COIN, exactly like the ones we saw in the opening.  19.

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: More of these...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: You sure you wanna know?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What? Are we gonna get a curse or something? | Oooocoochhhh. They all laugh, but not MACHEN.

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: It's the coin of greed. The coin of lust. The coin of doom. The PARTIERS look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You're freaky-deaky, old man. MACHEN checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: Five minutes till midnight. Not much time left... MACHEN turns towards the fire, staring into it.

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: In five minutes, it’11 be the twenty-first of April.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: So? MACHEN puts the coin on his tongue, the takes a swig of b

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: They’11 get nothin’ from me. Now MACHEN just stares, transe-like, into the crackling f There is a hushed silence as the PARTIERS just stare at t BEACHCOMBER. Only the HISS of the flames and then... THE SOUND OF AN ENGINE blasts open the silence as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps off onto the sand, obviously drunk. He’s got a camcorder in his hand, taping two BEAUTIFUL BLONDES in sweatshirts and bikini bottoms... And as they come off the boat, we realize one of the girl BRUNETTE, is actually wearing a blonde wig, which is star to fall off her head.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: (videotaping) Ladies. We have arrived. NICK comes running up, can’t believe his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: Nick! You know the twins. Mandi and Brandi.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: They’re not twins!

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: They’re not?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing, Spooner! SPOONER turns the camera on NICK.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: This is Nick Castle. As you can see, Nick’s a bit pisssed off right now. Let’s find out why...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Shut that thing off, shithead.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: (still taping) Wait a minute. Up there on the beach! Is that a... Yes. There's a party going on. Young men and women, cavorting around half-naked, polluting their bodies and minds. God, that sounds like fun. Let’s investigate!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Give me the keys, Spooner. SPOONER strolls past him with the TWINS in tow.  21.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: Relax, Nick. I left em on the boat. Nobody's gonna steal it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK climbs onto the flybridge. SEAN, ELIZABETH and EMILY walk down to the boat.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Want some help? NICK reaches in his pocket, tosses ELIZABETH his truck ke

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Take my truck to your mom’s. I‘1l come get it in the morning. I’ve gotta get this boat back to the marina.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Nick? Remember when you were gonna teach me to drive a stick?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You never did.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Look, Nick. You guys only got a couple days together. You take Elizabeth home. I/11 get Spooner and the boat back to the marina.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No, the boat’s my responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Dude, I can handle my dad’s 42-foot Bertram. I think I can handle this. ELIZABETH looks up at NICK without coaxing, wants him to the call. Finally, he sighs and we cut To:  22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVIE sorts through CD’s for tomorrow's shift, and for t first time we notice the WALL BEHIND HER, covered with a child's CRAYON DRAWINGS and construction paper ARTWORK. Beside her on the console is a photo of STEVIE with her a around a bright-eyed LITTLE BOY. STEVIE’S cellphone rings. She doesn’t check the display..

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Hi Andy... MAN’S VOICE (ON PHONE) Hello, darlin.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Hi Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You’re lonely over there without me, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Remind me why I gave you my cell number again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAN O’BANNON sits at a bank of glowing electronics in the tiny Coast Guard weather station.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Because I’m six feet of burnin’ love?

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: You're five-eight, Dan. And why are you still at work?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I traded shifts so I can go to the big party on Sunday. You gonna go?

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: I sleep on Sundays. Now tell me why you called, or I’m gonna hang up.  23.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Tell your boss you need the day off.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: I am the boss, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. Just thought you might like something to talk about.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: I’m listening.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I got something on my doppler a minute ago.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Sounds kinky.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Looks like a fog bank about twenty miles out. Moving inland. STEVIE opens a little ACCESS WINDOW in the glass, taps a GAUGE outside the lighthouse...

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Then my gauges must be wrong, ‘cause I show a wind blowing due East. What kind of fog moves against the wind?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You got me, but my radar doesn’t lie.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: This is very exciting stuff, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Hey. That’s what I’m here for.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: I gotta go. Buh-bye. STEVIE hangs up and hits a switch, leans into the mic.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: It’s a little after midnight on KAB. Stevie here, beaming my signal across the sea. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVIE (cont'd) Big Dan the Weatherman says there’s a fog bank rolling in offshore, so if I were you, I’d lock the doors and hide the keys...and whip up a pitcher of martinis while you listen to another hour of music on K.A.B. MUSIC UP as STEVIE cues another disk. She looks out over ocean, drinks a bottled water, shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: There’s no fog out there... curt TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEAN is at the helm of the SEAGRASS. The SONG Stevie just cued CONTINUES over the boat's stereo.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: There’s no fog out there... (yells) Spooner! You see any fog out there?

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE CAMCORDER VIEWFINDER
dialogues.text: We see the TWINS dancing, laughing, etc. SPOONER pans the horizon, then turns the lens on himself...

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER,
dialogues.text: There’s no fog out there! Back on the flybridge, SEAN continues looking anyway -- u the ENGINE starts to sputter. He checks the controls, eye going to the fuel gauge... EMPTY.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Shit! Spooner! We’re outta gas.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER,
dialogues.text: Dude. That sucks. SEAN whips out his cell. Display reads: NO SERVICE. Shit. He shakes his head at SPOONER, whose night is far from ruined, as he keeps right on dancing...  25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH sits close to NICK as they approach the outskir of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they speed by, we notice something they don’t. EVERY STREETLIGHT THEY PASS GOES OUT. And stays out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH puts her hand inside his shirt, lulled by the p of the engine.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I wish I could stay at your place tonight.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You could if you really wanted to. You could do alot of things if you really wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You're not still blaming me.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (yes) No.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You know why I left Antonio Bay, Nick. I had to. The only thing I didn’t want to leave...was you. SUDDENLY, THE TRUCK’S WINDOWS EXPLODE, SHATTERING INTO A

dialogues.speaker: MILLION PIECES
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH ducks, SCREAMING as glass FLIES everywhere. NIC drops down to protect her and the truck swerves to the si of the road, banging to a stop against the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On NICK and ELIZABETH, hunkered down in the cab as the du settles.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I think so.  26.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What the hell was that? And when they SIT UP... THERE'S A FIGURE LOOMING IN THE WINDOW! They both JUMP!

dialogues.speaker: FATHER MALONE
dialogues.text: A travesty. A hundred-year travesty...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Father Malone! FATHER MALONE is in his 40’s, handsome. In his prime, BOB MALONE was high school All-American, but those glory days now just yellowed clippings in some dusty scrapbook.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER MALONE
dialogues.text: Nicholas. Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Did you see what just happened? Did something hit us back there?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER MALONE
dialogues.text: I didn’t see. But then again... NICK gets a whiff of his breath, looks past him to the RA ALE on the corner. MALONE dangles his keys.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER MALONE
dialogues.text: ...I can’t seem to remember where I parked my car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEAN tries in vain to radio for help.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Coast Guard radio, this is the Seagrass, over... (changes the channel) Harbor Patrol, this is Seagrass, do you read, over? Shit! Nothing but STATIC. SEAN taps GENERATOR'S fuel gage -- 1/ tank left. At least they’ve got that...  27.

dialogues.speaker: ON DECK
dialogues.text: SPOONER is mixing cocktails, when the STATIC begins block out the signal from KAB. He goes over to mess with the stereo, when something OFF CAMERA grabs his attention. He puts the camcorder down (i is still running), goes over to the rail. A PULSING GLOW of bone-colored light, reflected on his fa

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: I think there’s a friggin’ fog bank out there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEAN turns, glances out the window. The unearthly light PULSATES on his FACE.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What the hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eerie WHITE WALL is almost upon them, lit from within some strange phosphorescent light. Soon, it blots out the entire horizon. Glowing. Throbbing. Swirling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPOONER backs away from the rail as THE FOG begins drifti into frame, flowing and shifting, enveloping the SEAGRASS We begin to HEAR A HOLLOW RUSHING SOUND, like BREATHING, ragged and phlegmy. SPOONER looks around, disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Spooner! What's out there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FOG drifts along the rear of the boat with a strange fluidity, almost WITH PURPOSE... As it reaches the GENERATOR HOLD, it SWEEPS DOWN, curling into the cracks and seams around the hold as if it knows precisely where it wants to go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPOONER and the girls come racing into the steering house SLAMMING the door behind them.  28.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: I can’t see shit! Turn on the... SPOONER stares at the instrument panel in shock. Everythi is going haywire. The compass needle SPINNING, indicators FLASHING on and off. The radio emits a HIGH-PITCHED SQUEA

dialogues.speaker: THE RADAR SCREEN
dialogues.text: A LARGE DOT PINGS close to the center.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: Christ! There’s something right in front of us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FOG drifts down and is INHALED BY THE CARBURETOR! The generator begins to CLANK and SMOKE and finally BREAKS DO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LIGHTS GO OUT.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: The generator! SPOONER grabs a FLASHLIGHT, races out of the steering hou leaving SEAN and the girls inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .SPOONER can barely see two feet in front of him as THE F continues to PULSE. The RUSHING sound grows louder with e passing moment. He clicks on the flashlight, swings the b down at

dialogues.speaker: GENERATOR HOLD
dialogues.text: BLACK SMOKE pours from the hold. SPOONER leans down to get a better view, when he hears a CREAKING NOISE beside the boat. He swings the flashlight around, points it into the fog.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: Hello! Is somebody out there!

dialogues.speaker: INTO THE FOG
dialogues.text: As the flashlight FINDS SOMETHING -- a thick, rusted CHAI rising out of the water. He follows it up to its source a we finally see it:  29.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: SEAN! You gotta see this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEAN hurries out of the wheelhouse, past the two girls, s the door hehind him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘SEAN runs up to find SPOONER shining the flashlight into mist. But there's nothing there.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: It’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What is!

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: Two seconds ago there was a...

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: There was a ship out there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GIRLS peer out the window, trying to see what’s going Suddenly there’s a banging at the door -- loud and even:

dialogues.speaker: KNOCK
dialogues.text: The REAL BLONDE goes to the door...

dialogues.speaker: REAL BLONDE
dialogues.text: Spooner? Is that you? ..and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPOONER and SEAN stand listening to a SOUND coming from t other end of the boat, like water dripping on the deck.  30.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: What is that? And now, FOOTSTEPS, coming towards them, closer, closer.. SPOONER shines the flashlight in that direction, BUT THER NOTHING THERE.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: We gotta get the hell outta here, Spooner. Suddenly, HYSTERICAL CRIES peal from the steering house. There’s a horrible THUDDING sound, as if bodies are being heaved and broken, then... DEAD SILENCE. SEAN and SPOONER are freaked out of their minds. They sta there in the quiet, frozen by fear, when...

dialogues.speaker: A BODY COMES SMASHING THROUGH THE STEERING HOUSE WINDOW,
dialogues.text: the deck with a wet smack. SPOONER shines the light down it’s one of the GIRLS -- wig askew, her body bent and twi in ways it was never meant to go. SPOONER turns to face SEAN, the flashlight wavering in hi hand, when suddenly... SEAN’S body JOLTS. His head snaps back, arms and legs spraddled, as if pinioned by some invisible, overwhelming force... ...and the following happens fast. THE FOG, formless at first, quickly compacts itself into something too grotesq to be human, but capable of very human movements... IT TAKES UP THE BONING KNIFE, inching it closer and close SEAN'S EYES...

dialogues.speaker: HELP ME SPOONER
dialogues.text: ON SPOONER NOW, eyes wide in horror, as we HEAR two obsce PUNCTURE SOUNDS. SPOONER backs up, stumbling. He catches himself, and when turns... The FOG is there, inches from his face. He tells himself this can’t be real...  31. THE FOG seizes hold of SPOONER’S neck, its “£ingers” pres the flesh on either side of his vertebrae. It rears back now, like a cobra about to strike, when SPOONER opens his mouth in a scream that never comes, as FOG suddenly DIVES DOWN HIS THROAT! And off the HORRIBLE SOUND of CARTILAGE and TISSUE being forced beyond their limits we

dialogues.speaker: AN OLD. STONE CHURCH
dialogues.text: Dark stone and bleeding mortar. Built to last. A SPIRE ju skyward in a tapered pike, housing the church’s CLOCKTOWE At its peak is a LARGE CROSS. The FACE AND HANDS OF THE CLOCK are black and without lus tarnished by a century’s exposure to the elements. They t us it is now HALF-PAST MIDNIGHT, and as we HEAR the’ SOUN an approaching vehicle, CAMERA BOOMS DOWN to:

dialogues.speaker: A CEMETERY
dialogues.text: Next door to the church. HEADLIGHTS splash over GRAVESTON a few of which are simple slabs, but most are more elabor as was the fashion at the turn of the century... NICK'S truck passes the cemetery, pulls to a stop in fron the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FATHER MALONE exits NICK'S truck, brushing chunks of safe glass off the seat of his pants.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You okay, Father? Want us to walk you in?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER MALONE
dialogues.text: I'll be fine. I’m afraid there's not near enough tribute paid to the miracle of sleep.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: G'night Father.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER MALONE
dialogues.text: Thank you for the ride. (turning back) Oh, and my brother...  32.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: He doesn’t need to know about this, does he?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER MALONE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Nick. It’s good to know I have two friends left in Antonio Bay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MALONE enters the cathedral as NICK'S truck pulls away. MOONLIGHT filters-in through stained glass windows. He walks down the aisle, steadying himself on the empty p muttering something about travesty as he goes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVIE shuts things down for the night, when something outside the window catches her eye... STEVIE’S POV -- a narrow FINGER OF FOG stretches inland, a bridge from the sea to the shore, that faint, pale GLOW within... She turns away -- that’s weird -- but it is, after all, o fog...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK stops in front of a quaint, two-story Victorian, tur off the engine.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You sure you don’t wanna... ELIZABETH puts her finger to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Don’t make this harder than it already is. Just kiss me. She kisses him gently, gets out. He watches her go, until her MOTHER opens the front door. ELIZABETH goes in, but h MOTHER just stands in the doorway, staring daggers at NIC He smiles big, gives her a little wave... She SLAMS the door loud, for effect.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: That went pretty well.  33. INT, ELIZABETH'’S HOUSE - NIGHT ELIZABETH comes in. Her mother, KATHY WILLIAMS -- mid 40’ pert and poised -- closes the door. There is no hug or ki

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: When you said a friend was picking you up, I didn’t think you meant him. And what’s on your face? KATHY wipes a tiny drop of BLOOD off ELIZABETH’S cheek (f the broken window). ELIZABETH pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Hello, Mother. Nice to see you, too. KATHY helps her in with her suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, darling. I just want more for you than I had. Is that such a crime?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: He’s right for me. Okay? Can we just drop it?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Okay. Fine. I was worried about you, off at school on your own. But you certainly look... Healthy.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What’s that supposed to mean? KATHY . Just looks like you've gained a few pounds, that’s all. They say that happens the first year away. ELIZABETH picks up her suitcase, heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I should've never come back.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: But I made hot cocoa. I thought we could stay up and talk, like we used to.  34.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I thought you loved hot cocoa!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I do. And KATHY is about to speak, when the front door SLAMS. EXT. ELIZABETH’S HOUSE - NIGHT ELIZABETH runs out into the street. NICK has turned the pickup around and is driving away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK sees her in his rearview mirror, waving at him. He stops as she catches up and gets in.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Change of plans.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Okay. What now?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Go to your place and have wild sex. NICK drives off with a smile, her words music to his ears curt To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FIRE crackles in the fireplace. We can hear ELIZABETH GIGGLING somewhere closeby. Strewn across the front room are NICK and ELIZABETH’S clo in a messy path, leading to THE BED, where the two of them lay cavorting, buried. und the covers. ELIZABETH’S head pops out, her hair messy -- sexy.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (under the covers) Come back here.  35.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Make me. NICK’S foot comes out, a monster searching for its prey. bites his toe. He yelps.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Mmmm. Tastes like chicken. NICK'S head pops out now, and they fall back onto the pillows. He leans over to kiss her, when A LOUD POUNDING THE DOOR startles them both.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Maybe if we don’t say anything they’11 go away.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s a she. Maybe I should get it. And as she starts to get up.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: We can see it from the bed, when...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (growling) Who is it!!! (there’s no reply) If that’s you, Spooner, I’m gonna kick your ass! And then...

dialogues.speaker: KNOCK
dialogues.text: Disgusted, NICK springs up, pulling on his boxers, stoppe what he sees next,

dialogues.speaker: THE .DOOR
dialogues.text: A BONE-COLORED LIGHT, PULSING just outside. Through the sidelights, we can see a SWIRLING MIST pressing against t glass. Something beyond appears to move now, a gray shadow in al the white, moving with lazy hypnotizing speed...  36.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What the hell...

dialogues.speaker: THE DOORKNOB
dialogues.text: NICK reaches for it, WHIPS open the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes out onto the porch, looks out. NICK'S POV - On the BEACH, as the wall of FOG roils back to sea. ELIZABETH comes out now, wrapped in nothing but a blanket

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Who was it?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I don’t know. He stands there, scanning the beach for some sign of life There's nothing but empty beach and dark ocean., so he tu to go back inside, when...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That’s weird. She points. He looks.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Those footprints. Like somebody walked out of the water, right up to the door.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEACH
dialogues.text: The FOOTPRINTS lead from the ocean up to his door. But th rest of the beach is completely smooth, washed clean by t tide...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glistening BLACK CRAB darts into a crevice as a WAVE CRASHES ON THE ROCKS... WHITE WATER SPRAYS across the screen, and as the froth recedes, we can see SOMETHING SHINY, wedged between the rocks...  37.

dialogues.speaker: A FRESH-FACED LITTLE BOY
dialogues.text: Comes bounding up the beach. This is the boy we saw in th PHOTO. He plays a game with the tide, trying to stay dry, sending the sandpipers scurrying, when SOMETHING CATCHES EYE. He walks over, bends down to see something GOLD, glinting the sunlight, half-buried in the sand. Another wave crashes down. The BOY reaches for the thing, and when the water recedes, HE GRABS IT... He holds it up, wiping away the sand and slime, when we realize it’s THE GOLD HAIRBRUSH from the opening, caked w crud, its bristles eaten away by the sea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front room is cozy, lots of wood and stone, with a fantastic wall of GLASS DOORS looking out at the beach. Through them, we see the BOY run by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOMEBODY is sound asleep in bed as the BOY blasts through door.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Mom! Wake up! Look what I found! There is no movement, so the BOY rips down the covers to STEVIE curled up in her t-shirt and panties.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Ubhhgggghhh. Hi Andy... He drops his wet and sandy swag on the pillow beside her. The first thing she sees when she opens her eyes...

dialogues.speaker: . BOY, (ANDY)
dialogues.text: I found it on the beach. Between some rocks! I think it’s gold!

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: We should be so lucky...

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It’s heavy. Feel.  38. STEVIE picks it up, tests its heft, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Must’ve been somebody’s hairbrush once upon a time... STEVIE puts it down, smiles warmly and kisses her son.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: So. Wanna go out for breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (jumps off the bed) Yeah, but first I wanna go back down to the beach. Maybe the tide washed up more stuff!

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Half an hour, okay? I’ve got to go in a little early today.’ Maybe Mrs. Kobritz will help you look.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Mom. Please. All she does is eat Tim-Tams and watch Wheel of Fortune. ANDY races out. STEVIE sits there for a moment. She smile when she sees ANDY past the window - a mother watching he son grow up. Then she glances down at the brush. INT. STEVIE’S BATHROOM - SINK - DAY STEVIE holds the brush under running water, wiping away layers of gunk and slime, revealing the intricate etching the back. She rubs it dry with a towel, and underneath, i shiny -- like gold. Hmmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK turns over in bed, blindly reaching for ELIZABETH, opening his eyes when he realizes she’s not there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH sits on the beach, a blanket around her shoulde She digs her toes into the sand, enjoying the crash of th waves and the heat of the sun -- the perfect morning.  39. NICK comes out, hands her a cup of coffee, kisses her on head. .

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I think the beach is the only thing I really miss. (off his look) You. And the beach. We HEAR NICK'S PHONE ringing inside the house.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hold that thought. He runs inside. She gets up, wandering down to the hard sand. She picks up a seashell, admiring it, when she hear NICK shout from the deck:

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Elizabeth! She turns to him, instantly worried by the look on his fa

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Spooner and Sean never made it back last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The marina buzzes with activity, fishing boats CREWING-UP the day’s charters, etc. NICK AND ELIZABETH stand beside the SEAGRASS’ empty slip, talking to HANK JONES, the harbor master.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: ...set out last night around nine- thirty. Hadn't been heard from since...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Spooner order any fuel yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Nothing in the log.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Unbelievable. I’m gonna need a favor, Hank. Think we could borrow your Whaler?  40.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Sure. Key’s in it. You want me to call the Coast Guard?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Nah. They probably just got drunk and passed out. Let’s keep this between us for now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLASTING through the water with NICK at the wheel. ELIZAB scans the horizon with binocs.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Could they be this far out?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Not unless they were drifting all night.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Wait! I think I see it! She hands NICK the binocs and points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BOAT, about a mile out, drifting on the swells, its dec deserted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the Seagrass, alright...

dialogues.speaker: A BRISTLY GREEN HORSEFLY
dialogues.text: BUZZES into frame, landing on a SLIMY PIECE OF SEAWEED, w

dialogues.speaker: WHAM
dialogues.text: TWO FEET land beside, scaring it off, and we WIDEN TO REV NICK, who's just jumped onto the deck of the SEAGRASS.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Spooner? Sean! There’s no reply and no sign of life (or death) on deck. NICK helps ELIZABETH aboard.  41.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Maybe somebody picked them up. NICK notices some BROKEN GLASS on the deck, looks up to s the shattered STEERING HOUSE WINDOW.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door CREAKS open. NICK steps inside. He goes to the window, notices BLOOD on the broken glass. He looks down the CONTROLS, turns to ELIZABETH:

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Look at these gauges. They’re all shattered.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Like your truck.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah... (to himself) What the hell happened here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK enters the corridor of the main cabin, sets about checking every door...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Spooner!

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE DECK
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH exits the steering house, notices a FISHING ROD in the arm of the fighting chair. Its line has been cast. ° ELIZABETH Would they’ve been fishing?

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Why?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: There’s a line in the water...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head -- none of this makes any sense.  A2.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I have no clue, Reel it in for me, will you, before we lose the rig. NICK reaches the last door in the cabin, open just a crac He pushes it. Slowly, it CREAKS inward to REVEAL... SOMEONE LYING ON THE BED, facing away from us, hair wet a matted with SEAWEED...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Sean?

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON DECK
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH muscles the reel, the rod tip bending under the strain.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Nick! There’s something on this line...

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE CABIN
dialogues.text: _ NICK moves to the bed, reaches out tentatively, when THE BODY LOLLS OVER ONTO ITS BACK and we see SEAN'S HOLLO

dialogues.speaker: EYE SOCKETS GAPING OUT AT US
dialogues.text: NICK recoils, hitting the wall, backing out the door befo he vomits...

dialogues.speaker: ON DECK
dialogues.text: NICK stumbles out of the cabin, leans over the rail, hear pounding. ELIZABETH keeps reeling, LOOKS OVER AT HIM.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Nick! What is it? And she’s still focused on NICK, when we SEE SOMETHING AP JUST BENEATH THE SURFACE OF THE WATER at the end of her line... HUMAN BODIES, pale, bent and broken, fish-bitten ARMS and LEGS and FLOWING BLONDE HAIR, bound tight in a tangle of fishing line... ...and just when we realize it’s the TWINS -- or what’s l of them... THE LINE SNAPS! ELIZABETH turns back, catching only the slightest glimpse, as the BLOATED CORPSES sink out of sig  43.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: He comes over to her, following her gaze...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What was it?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I don't know, I couldn’t tell. It looked like...bodies.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Jesus. C’mon. I’m getting you off this boat.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (stopping him) Tell me what you saw in the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: We've gotta deal with this together, Nick! Now tell me!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Sean. He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Dead?!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah! He's fucking dead, alright! (beat, then). I’m sorry. Let’s just get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK helps ELIZABETH into the Whaler, but doesn’t get in himself.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: There’s one place I didn’t check.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Nick...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Two seconds. Wait here.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (as he leaves) Nick... Nick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. NICK enters the hold, has a look around. notices the GENERATOR, coated with a thin film of salt crystals. He touches it -- that makes no sense...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH hugs herself, suddenly feeling very alone, when HEARS SOMETHING CREAK on deck. She stands up, looking towards the sound, and in a thin voice:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Nick? Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK stands up -- nothing more to see here. He exits the hold, SLAMMING the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back on deck, NICK approaches the WHALER, can’t believe h eyes. It’s EMPTY -- ELIZABETH is nowhere in sight!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Elizabeth!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH wanders belowdecks looking for NICK, when she notices something OFF CAMERA. She walks over, kneeling in front of the FREEZER, picks u SLIMY PIECE OF SEAWEED... She looks up, registering THE FREEZER. She reaches for th handle and gives it a pull, but the thing won’t budge. Sh tugs again, harder this time, but still no joy. She puts her feet against the wall, gives it one last YAN and this time the DOOR WHOOSHES OPEN! ELIZABETH SCREAMS!! THERE'S A PERSON IN THE FREEZER!!! BLUE from the cold, HA COVERED IN ICE CRYSTALS. IT’S SPOONER! Is he DEAD? He mus be. In fact, we're sure of it, until...  45.

dialogues.speaker: IN A FROZEN RICTUS, TUMBLING OUT WITH A FROSTBITTEN THUD
dialogues.text: cur To:

dialogues.speaker: A PLATINUM CLOUD OF FOG
dialogues.text: BILLOWING, SWIRLING, SPREADING. Something beyond our visi appears to be MOVING in all that white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FIGURE begins to materialize, hovering dreamlike within mist...

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: ...what do you mean, you'll ‘take care of me’? That deal doesn’t happen without me, Tom, and you know it. KATHY WILLIAMS emerges from the fogbank, wearing a tapere suit, and moving with zeal and authority. She is followed SHERIFF MALONE who waves the smoky haze away from his fac we WIDEN to reveal...

dialogues.speaker: A BANDSTAND
dialogues.text: Has been erected in the park. FOG MACHINES are PUMPING Hollywood-style FOG into the air. MULTI-COLORED LIGHTS FL AND PIVOT on overhead towers, as the TECH-CREW does a dry for the band’s big performance. MALONE looks back, takes-in all the pyrotechnics..

dialogues.speaker: TOM MALONE
dialogues.text: In my day, it was all about the music.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Don’t jerk me around, Tom! A harried young WOMAN passes by, her hands full of stream and bunting, etc.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Lauren! Did you get all the promos over to Stevie at the lighthouse?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am.  46.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Good. And what about the porta- potties? I don’t see my porta- potties!

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: On the way.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I hope so. KATHY dismisses LAUREN with a wave, turns on TOM.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: A percentage, Tom. That was the deal. Those were the terms.

dialogues.speaker: TOM MALONE
dialogues.text: Relax. A Malone never goes back on his word. Once this thing’s closed you'll get every penny you’re due. We all will. And off KATHY'S skeptical eyes, we

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. STEVIE’S CONVERTIBLE - DAY STEVIE drives the coast highway en route to the lighthous her dark hair whipping in the wind. We may notice some TRAFFIC in the other direction, headed into town for the big celebration... ON THE SEAT BESIDE HER are two things: The GOLD HAIRBRUSH from the beach, and a CD CASE labeled KAB - BIRTHDAY PROM Over the RADIO, WE HEAR AN ANNOUNCER’S TAG, then a hokey little JINGLE:

dialogues.speaker: CHORUS
dialogues.text: It’s one hundred years ago today, so sit back, stow your cares away, Just smile, and take the time to say, “Happy Birthday, Antonio Bay”. From your friends at Thriftway Cleaners!

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Ugghh. How perky...  47. She ejects the CD, tosses it onto the seat beside her, wh HER EYES FIND THE BRUSH. And now, as if drawn to the thin she CAN'T TAKE HER EYES OFF IT... CLOSE ON THE BRUSH - and STEVIE’S REFLECTION in it, when.

dialogues.speaker: A HORN BLARES
dialogues.text: STEVIE looks up, sees AN ONCOMING CAR. At the last second SHE SWERVES back into her lane, a heartbeat from disaster

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An EMT AMBULANCE is parked on the dock, doors open, LIGHT FLASHING. TOM MALONE squeals up in his SHERIFF'S TRUCK...

dialogues.speaker: EXT, SEAGRASS
dialogues.text: The SEAGRASS has been towed-in, and is now moored at the of the pier. The EMT’S have SPOONER on a gurney. He’s wrapped in foil blankets, just now beginning to regain hi color. NICK and ELIZABETH stand close by, concerned for their friend, as TOM MALONE strides up the pier...

dialogues.speaker: TOM MALONE
dialogues.text: Somebody wanna tell me what the hell happened out there? SPOONER says nothing, his glassy eyes staring off without seeing. Frustrated, MALONE turns to NICK and ELIZABETH.

dialogues.speaker: TOM MALONE
dialogues.text: He tell you two anything?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: He hasn't said a word since we found him.

dialogues.speaker: TOM MALONE
dialogues.text: ‘Course not. (facing NICK) Tell me somethin’, Hotrod. Why is it whenever there’s trouble, I always see your smilin’ face?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Same ol’ shit...  48.

dialogues.speaker: TOM MALONE
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: This is not about Nick, and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM MALONE
dialogues.text: I guess we’ll find that out, won’t we, College girl. HANK JONES walks up to MALONE.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Tom. Coast Guard wants to talk to you on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: TOM MALONE
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s just great. Tell ‘em I'll be right there. (pointing at NICK) We got one dead and two missing. You tell your pal he better limber up that jaw... And when MALONE has gone, SPOONER reaches out with a shivering hand, catches NICK’S arm in a grip so tight, it makes him wince.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: There’s something out there, Nick.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s alright, Spooner. You don’t have to talk now...

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: ...something in the Fog. It killed Sean! ON ELIZABETH - as this really resonates with her.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Just take it easy, man. Everything’s gonna be fine. And as THE EMT’S wheel him away, SPOONER looks off, stuck with a reality no one will buy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. STEVIE‘S CONVERTIBLE - MARINA - DAY STEVIE slows as she approaches the commotion at THE MARIN She recognizes SPOONER being loaded into the AMBULANCE. S pulls over and gets out as the ambulance drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVIE walks up the pier, where HANK JONES is talking to FISHERMEN.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Hey, Stevie.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Hank. Was that Brett Spooner?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah. ‘Fraid so.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Accident on the Seagrass. Pretty bad, I guess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK is battening down the SEAGRASS, doesn’t see STEVIE walking up the pier...

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Hi Nick. NICK turns. She smiles at him, warm and genuine, nothing else on it. Even so, his body tenses, eyes darting to the HARBORMASTER’S SHACK...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Stevie. What’re you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Not exactly a Hallmark greeting there, Nick.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. (then) How are you?  50.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: How am I as in, how’s the weather? Or how am I as in you really wanna know.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: The second one.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: I’m good.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Really.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (he's surprised) Cool. You know, ‘cause I...

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: (letting him off the hook) I saw them take Spooner away in the ambulance. Hank said there was an accident? Behind STEVIE, we see ELIZABETH exiting the HARBORMASTER' SHACK, a BLANKET around her shoulders. NICK sees her too.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Elizabeth! Look who’s here...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Stevie?

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Hey, look at you! You look so...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Grown up... The two friends HUG. ELIZABETH holds on a little too long STEVIE notices.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Elizabeth? What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Sean Reed's dead.  51.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: They were out on the Seagrass last night. Spooner said he saw something in the fog. Whatever it was killed Sean.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: (too absurd for her) The fog killed Sean?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Elizabeth...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Spooner’s alot of things, Nick. But he’s no liar. You saw his face! Something out there scared him to death.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: We found him stuffed in the freezer hold. He was pretty whacked out. They said another few minutes and he wouldn't have made it. The two girls with him are still missing. ANGLE ON ELIZABETH - glancing into the water, recalling w she saw, or what she might’ve seen, when...

dialogues.speaker: TOM MALONE
dialogues.text: I need everybody away from this boat. And don’t touch anything from the crime scene.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Crime scene?

dialogues.speaker: / TOM MALONE
dialogues.text: You see that dead boy’s eyes?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I saw ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: TOM MALONE
dialogues.text: They didn’t get that way by accident. Now get off the boat...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Alright, alright. I heard you the first time...  52. NICK is about to disembark, when he notices the CAMCORDER lying where SPOONER left it. He makes sure MALONE’S not looking, then He shoves the CAMCORDER under his shirt and goes. cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: THE LIGHTHOUSE
dialogues.text: Tall and majestic in the afternoon sun. EMBLAZONED on the side is KAB 94.5. STEVIE pulls up in her convertible, gathers her stuff and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVIE enters through the door at the base of the lightho moving past some work closets, storage cabinets, etc. She ascends the three-story SPIRAL STAIRCASE that leads to...

dialogues.speaker: BROADCAST BOOTH
dialogues.text: STEVIE comes in and dumps her stuff (including the BRUSH) a console by the wall, singing a little ditty of her own:

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: I don’t wanna work today, so everybody, go away. Cause Stevie wants to shop and play... She hits some buttons and flips some switches and the station's electronics start to WHIRR.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: ...let some other poor sap do my broadcast today. STEVIE pops the PROMOS disk into the CD tray. She takes a apple from her bag, starts slicing it into pieces with a knife. In the b.g., we HEAR the ANNOUNCER TAG another dum BIRTHDAY jingle...

dialogues.speaker: CHORUS
dialogues.text: Hap-py Birthday, from your friends at Pet-World, Hap-py Birthday. Antonio-o Bay... STEVIE shakes her head -- pathetic. She sits down in her chair, slips off her shoes and rolls across the room to h computer.  53. She fires it up, glancing at the meters and dials on the wall, when we notice A RED GLOW RISING ON THE SIDE OF HER FACE. She feels it now, and slowly, she turns...

dialogues.speaker: THE GOLD BRUSH
dialogues.text: GLOWING RED HOT on the console! The years of sea-grit BUR AWAY! WISPS OF SMOKE APPEAR NOW, as THE CONSOLE UNDERNEAT

dialogues.speaker: THE BRUSH BEGINS TO MELT
dialogues.text: STEVIE stares at it in disbelief, when IN HER EYES, we se

dialogues.speaker: THE BRUSH
dialogues.text: Has ignited ONE OF ANDY’S CRAYON DRAWINGS tacked to the w above the console. In an instant, another one catches and now THE WALL IS ON FIRE!

dialogues.speaker: WITH STEVIE
dialogues.text: As she races down the spiral staircase. The throws open o of the storage closets, pulls out a FIRE EXTINGUISHER... cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: THE SCREEN BECOMES A WHITE-OUT FROM WHICH EMERGES
dialogues.text: STEVIE, firing a blast of CO2. As the dust settles, THE FIRST THING WE NOTICE is THE HOLE IN THE CONSOLE TOP -- a perfect outline of the BRUSH, which has melted completely through. But, underneath, THE BRUSH HAS VANISHED, and we WIDEN to The fire has SCORCHED THE PLASTER where the art once hung REVEALING A WEIRD PATTERN on the lighthouse wall. Maybe a window, or a trap door was here once, but it has long sin been BRICKED-IN. STEVIE reaches up, brushing away blistered plaster, when ONE OF THE BRICKS comes loose in its mortar. She pokes at curiously, SURPRISED WHEN IT GIVES WAY, and we can HEAR i fall into the hollow of the wall... She drops the fire extinguisher and stands there, staring the open hole. She leans in, peering into the void, but i PITCH DARK in there and she can’t see a thing. She jimmies a few more bricks loose, drops them on the fl With more light now, she sticks her head in...  54. STEVIE’S POV - INSIDE THE WALL SHE SEES SOMETHING wedged between the studs, but the ligh doesn’t quite hit it. Whatever it is, it appears to be wrapped, or wound in something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVIE'S ARM REACHES IN...fingers feeling around blindly, straining for the thing, but she can’t quite reach it, wh

dialogues.speaker: SOMETHING LASHES AROUND HER WRIST
dialogues.text: ON STEVIE’S TERRIFIED FACE As she tries to pull her arm from the hole! THE LIGHTS an ELECTRONICS in the room begin to flicker and buzz, and whatever has her, PULLS HER INTO THE WALL, with force eno to send the rest of the bricks cascading down around her. SHE FALLS, SHRIEKING in horror at what’s now attached to hand!

dialogues.speaker: AND UNDULATING SEAWEED
dialogues.text: She goes for a pair of SCISSORS on the desk, HACKING AT T SLIMY MASS. YELLOW OOZE spurts from the SEAWEED TENDRILS, whatever it is FINALLY LETS GO and the book falls to the floor. _She checks her wrist where the thing had hold of her -- puffy, rising welts... She looks down at the book, only now, it’s just a dusty o leatherbound book. No sign of anything strange. She tilts her head to make out the gold-embossed words on book’s cover...

dialogues.speaker: JOURNAL OF PATRICK MALONE
dialogues.text: INT. STEVIE’S BEACH HOUSE - DAY The PHONE RINGS as an OLDER WOMAN in a brightly-colored housedress enters carrying a grocery bag. Her eyeglasses hang around her neck on a decorative chain, and we recogn her as the WOMAN who scooped up the money from the ATM machine...

dialogues.speaker: OLDER WOMAN
dialogues.text: Andy, the telephone...  55.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I got it, Mrs. Kobritz! ANDY comes running from the bedroom, grabs the phone.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVIE on the phone, staring at the BOOK ON THE FLOOR...

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Andy, it’s me. Where did you find the gold brush, honey?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It’s gold? I told you it was gold! I knew it!

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Where did you find it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: On the rocks, out by the point.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: I want you to stay away from there, okay? Don’t pick up anything else from the beach, do you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It didn’t belong to anybody...

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: I know, sweetie. It’s okay. I just don’t want you to pick up anything else unless I’m with you. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Good. Is Mrs. Kobritz there?’

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Yeah.  56.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: {calming down a bit) How’s Wheel of Fortune?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: She just got here. She’s probably still unpacking the Tim-Tams...

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Okay. I love you and I want you to promise me you won’t go down to the beach again without me.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Aw, Mom...

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Okay. I promise. Bye. STEVIE hangs up. She looks over at the HOLE IN THE WALL, then at the JOURNAL, utterly, chillingly confused. Then, makes a decision. She takes off her sweatshirt, throws it over the book, th kicks at it to be sure it’s “dead”. Satisfied, she brings a wastebasket over, and in one quic motion, scoops up the book and dumps it in, keeping her distance... She goes to her computer, types something in. The DISPLAY READS: PRE-RECORDED TRACKS - 60:00. She hits ENTER and th meter starts ticking down. She checks her watch, picks up the WASTEBASKET and goes.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SPOONER’S HOSPITAL ROOM - LATE AFTERNOON SPOONER lays back in his bed, pale and MOANING as a young NURSE takes his temperature.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: How are we feeling? SPOONER just moans.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Tell me where it hurts.  57.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: It's just... This burning pain...

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Where? He points to his abdomen. She touches him.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Here?

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: Down lower.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Here?

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: No. Little lower... She’s down to his groin now, starts to touch him there, w she looks up, miffed when she sees HIS GRINNING FACE.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: (reads the thermometer) Your temperature’s back to normal.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: I could’a told you that. As the NURSE exits the room, NICK and ELIZABETH enter.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: Don't you just love those little nurse outfits. ELIZABETH hands him a styrofoam cup.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Brought you some chicken soup.

dialogues.speaker: SPOONER
dialogues.text: Yummy. How ‘bout a beer to go with it. NICK and ELIZABETH trade a look...
